Hey Ellis (Post #11): What about Trinity's men's squash? I think they're at 224 right now. . .I'm surprised you didn't mention them seeing as you're listed as from CT. And, we're not talking about any college winning streak. We're talking about NCAA Div I college basketball.

U-C-O-N-N UCONN! UCONN! UCONN! GO HUSKIES!!
Yes, UCANN! Bravo!!!!!

Sorry to be a wet blanket here, but UCLA won 88 straight games playing quality opponents who were at or near their level. UConn's women's team has won 89 consecutive games by an average margin of 33 points, with only two opponents finishing within ten points of them. When NCAA women's basketball finally manages to accumulate enough quality players and teams to create reasonably competitive schedules for teams that otherwise simply vacuum up the few elite women players (think Murray Bergtrum in NYC girls' high school basketball as another example), perhaps then we can talk about a team like UConn in the same breath as Wooden and UCLA. Until then, it's all newspaper-selling hype, no better than comparing the Harlem Globetrotters' win streak to honestly competitive sports. Sorry, but nobody's going to convince me that any current women's college basketball teams belong in the same sentence as the Alcindor/Walton/Wilkes/Worthy/Shackleford/et.al. teams.

How about having an affordable health care system, like in most civilized countries, that would not force you out on the street? I see a big problem in squeezing the lower middle class more and more and only give people help when they become homeless. And although there is a big problem with our government and our political system where two sites fight over everything like spoiled little kids; I see it more as a problem of  the economical system. As if we were going back to feudalism.

I read an article a few years ago that focused on one individual, I believe in Denver, that was chronically homeless. The only thing he needed to get clean, search for work, etc. was getting him into housing first. The most astonishing part of the article was the extremely high costs associated with his homelessness. I am excited to see organizations joining together with this knowledge and acting on it.

People become homeless for many reasons. Some are genuine and deserve our attention and intervention. But in this country many people become homeless by choice (Drug abuse, high school drop outs, those who cannot keep jobs etc).  If you ask social workers, they will tell you several instances where they tried to get homes for this people but they go right back to streets. First and foremost such people need to take responsibility for their lives. Otherwise no one can help them. You can take a horse to the water but cannot make it drink. Wasting tax payers money on these types is not worthwhile.

A real apples and oranges comparison. Hundreds of men's college teams woud beat the UCONN women's team every time. If you need proof, a few years ago the American Women's Olympic basketball team, which easily won the Olympics, lost many games to pick-up men's teams.

Some of the commenters seem to assume certain things that are not necessarily true.  For example, it is not likely that homeless people are given houses with mortgages.  It is more likely that they are housed in rooms and/or apartments built for this purpose or adapted for this purpose.  They are not "given" services without involving them in their own efforts towards improved living, whether it is outright independence or continued communal living.  What is different in this approach, is that stable housing is provided first, with services appropriate to their needs following.  The statistics quoted indicate that our assumptions about why people are homeless are not necessarily true.  But the most important thing about any program is matching services to needs. In our community in Chicago, there is a relatively small program called Hyde Park Transitional Housing, that serves carefully screened families, provides a furnished apartment for them, and provides training and mentoring over a period of time for the parents and children.  The goal is independence.  Other homelessness programs target people with different needs.  That is as it should be.  The Hyde Park program is not a government program.  But the people connected with it are involved in promoting workable government as well as private programs.  We need community collaboration to end homelessness.

#17: If 120,000 people are chronically homeless, how can LA's 4,800 chronically homeless people equal 10% of the chronically homeless population?

The article states 10% of LA's chronically homeless, not the total for the US.

I live in gainesville, Florida and worked with the homeless clinic here in town. We are awful to our homeless population as a city. We have a growing population of people, some families, who live on the street full-time. I have met several people over time and everyone is unique and had different reasons for ending up homeless. Our city has implemented a feeding restriction for the homeless. Any number of people over 130 will be turned away. With the economy as it is and people losing their homes and facing situations that, under normal circumstances, they would not face, it is beyond what is good or right to turn people away who are hungry, especially when there is typically enough food to feed everyone.
When i worked for the clinic the one thing that was most needed was housing. The homeless had devoloped a tent-city in an industrial area on the outskirts of town but they were chased out by authorities due to businesses complaining. They cannot sleep in parks. What do they do then?

I would love to see your organization incoporated into the Gainesville community and would be glad to help that happen. I agree that it is absurd to wait until people are 'up to par' to give them somewhere to sleep safely. It would seem to me that giving them shelter and a safe place to live would encourage them to try and do more. Why would they 'clean up' only to face the harsh reality of life on the streets? Anyone with any common sense could understand why a person who is living on the streets may want to numb themselves to that reality.

A Very Wise Man once said "You will always have the poor among you". This also can be said of the homeless. The author has given many reasons why they are homeless. I'm sure the surveys taken and excuses given are real,or at least perceived as real. Having said that,and lived through the "Evil Ronald Reagan" welfare incentives, where the poor and homeless were expected to perform some menial task for the the roof over their head. This turned out to be to much to ask. Many when asked to perform 20 hours community service, opted out!

Let's learn from the past shall we;

Government run institutions for the mentally ill was deemed cruel and inhuman several decades ago by our wonderful court system.

The government stepped in and built entire buildings (Monuments) to house the poor and only created more ghettos that had to be bulldozed to the ground!

Setting up smaller communities in established neighborhoods only brought in additional crime and drugs, not to mention destroying the value of the surrounding homes.

So, where does that leave us? If a person wants help, he or she has to work on improving their situation. Without effort, freebe's are enablers! Stop the handouts and expect something in return. Generate a little "self respect"! 90% of these people could and must participate in society! The other 10% who are genuinely mentally ill will require more difficult solutions!

Often when I see a homeless person I ask myself, where is their family? The question is rhetorical, as I had a close relative who was homeless. With all the love I had for him, I wasn't able to help; his needs were too immense for me.

And so, I was thrilled to read this article this morning, about people who can (and do) reach out and help. My relative passed away last summer. I know for certain, someone sitting beside him and asking what he wanted, rather than assuming his own good, would have been his miracle.
Thanks David for this story on Rosanne Haggarty's vital work to understand the roots of homelessness as a lifecycle paradigm, not a personal stigma of failure or just reward.
Just when I'm ready to give up on the human race I find another group of dedicated people who really work to make a difference in how people are treated.  Good going and may it sprea!

We volunteer to help a ministry that helps people overcome life long addictions. Many chronic illnesses are also gone as people deal with the root of the mind body connections. I believe you need to get to the root of why many people are homeless to help them start a new life. It is great that these people are offered housing but much more is needed. Without getting to the root of the problem, a normal life is not within reach for many of these individuals. I want to see these people have a totally new start in every aspect, not just a home. Several years ago I invited homeless people to live with me for a time and even though each one of them were given their own bedroom they all ended up sleeping on the floor in a huddle in our family room. They were in a big home with lots of room but they were still living in a way that was familiar to them. I had a revelation from this experience that more than providing them a place to live was needed. I have seen many disturbed people, homeless, sick, depressed, etc. start a new life through the organization RLI. They have conferences through the Tri-State and even though it is quite an expense to put on a conference they never turn away someone who doesn't have the ability to pay for the conference.
www.restoringlivesinternational.com

If you know someone homeless or not that needs help with the things I mentioned(emotional, physical, addictions) refer them to this organization. It is a place they will never be judged and will always feel loved.

You can't force people to live in housing, apartments or SRO hotels if they don't want to do so.
"As of today, 6,816 people have been housed "

That's a tiny, tiny number of people who live on the streets, in their cars or trailers for various reasons.

"“We learned that the only way to get chronically homeless people into housing was to go out and beg them to let us help them,”"

That's hardly a viable model of social outreach. How long do these people stay in housing, once they've been begged to move in?

#48,

The great society programs all failed?

Really. This is not self-evident. This country has problems, no doubt about it. But ask yourself how bad it might have been without social security, or without medicare and medicate. Would you prefer to step over dead bodies on your way to work?

Yes, we do show a marked inclination to underfund programs, then complain when they don't work. But this is article proved that when people went all out to fix a problem -- not just throw a band-aid on it, they succeeded.. And the extra benefit -- in the end, it will save money.

Now think about what it might mean to actually improve our schools. Or offer really good prenatal care, and early childhood education. Time and again studies show that these things work. But the naysayers, without any data, love to say they don't. They point to an imperfect world and say, "see, there are still problems." That's not an argument.

Whatever happens to a family value of keeping family together no matter what problems that family member has? Drug addiction, mental illness, gambling, poverty, divorce, violent crime, imprisonment, professional failure, disabilities, single parenthood, long-term illness, etc. Family should be the first and only one to take responsibility for that person's well being before it becomes a burden draining the community's resources.

Due to my mental health issues, I've had all the problems mentioned above (and even more that you can only imagine!), but my family always supports me and takes me back in. They're too ashamed to let me beg from strangers or apply for unemployment benefits or welfare checks. In fact, they each hold at least two low-paying jobs. Moreover, they've put up with my violent episodes, my repeated problems with the outside world and almost everything I can do to disrupt peace in our cramped, old house.

It's our inner value toward family, either in close and strained relationships, that needs to be fixed. No amount of money in the whole world can resolve homelessness until the work is done from inside out. Charity starts at home.

The idea of finding a home, i.e., stability, for a homeless person before working on the other issues is not new, and in some cities it has been abandoned because it often results in postpoining work on the other issues until the scarce housing can be found for the "client" and accepted by him or her.  Adjusting back to four walls after life on the streets is not easy, and it is often resistied by the object of the helpers.  In some cases, all the issues, including housing, have to be confronted both seriously and serially at the same time. Ripeness, Shakespeare said, is all.
